title: Exotic mangrove forest and caves
review_text: From Port Blair it takes around 3 to 4 hrs to reach Baratang Port from where you will have to take a speedboat ride through mangrove forest and then a 10 mins hike through forest. Naturally formed limestone caves which is believed to be under the sea at one point of time.

title: Naturally formed Limestone CAVES
review_text: The caves are near Baratang. This is accessible only through a speed boat from Baratang (A&N). The sea journey in speed boat is really enjoyable since it covers thick mangrove growths on eitherside and narrow waterways amongst these dense Mangrove forest formations. Really eco friendly surroundings. On reaching There is wooden erected platforms to enable tourists to cross over Mangroves and reach the land. About 1.5KM walk is really worth once you reach the Limestone caves. This is naturally formed Caves and there are lime formations which is unique and really amazing. Various lime formations give us similarity to real models like lion's paw. Never miss the cave if you happen to go to A & N. More

title: Natural caves made up of lime
review_text: Lime caves are natural caves made up of lime stone. After reaching baratang island, a speed boat with take you to mangrove forest and then after a walk of 1.5 KM, you will reach this amazing place. The stone of cave is of different color due to impact of light and sun rays as entering into cave from small holes. Differnt shapes has been created naturally in these caves.

title: Superb
review_text: The long journey to baratang that starts at 3 in the mornings is worth the pain of the travel passing the reserved forests of Jarawa tribes on the way the gates of which open only at regulated tons few times a day. The road journey is followed by a public ferry then private motor boat through the mangroves followed by a trek. The natural caves with a variety of naturally formed figures are a delight

title: Baratang Trip
review_text: Limestone caves have deteriorated and hardly any left to view. The boat ride ad investing 1 complete day is not worth it for the place . Though the mangrove forest boat ride will be good and gazing at the river side you might spot a crocodile. The guides will rush you through the trip. This area is too warm due to special trees around so make sure to carry your cap and sun creams along.

title: Title
review_text:
Awesome experience. Boat ride through dense mangroves on the way to Limestone caves is really, really awesome. 

:-)

title: Pretty much a journey worth remembering
review_text:
A visit to Limestone Caves located in Baratang Island is one of its kind . The journey is worth it . You have to start at 2 am at night from Port Blair in order to reach the checkpost . After obtaining the permit , you need to go through Jarawa tribal forest area to reach Bartang Pier . From there you will have to take a boat to reach the Limestone caves. 

Limestone caves have naturally forming Limestone figures of different shapes and sizes. 

Highly recommended 
Notes : Do wear proper shoes .

title: Nature in innovation
review_text: The Mangrove walkway,the jungle trek trail,the awe inviting cave with dripping water,and the ever changing limestone formations is worth seeing.Hire a speed boat from baratang jetty to the limes stone cave.the best part of the travel apart from the limes stone formation is the boat ride through the thick mangrove forest.your boat man will be your guide.

title: Mangrove forest..limeatone caves..
review_text: The day started too early ..2.30m we started from portblair to reach the spot from where the convoy starts. The reserved forest area which you move through for an hour and a half, under security and in a convoy if about 25 vehicles . so there are 2 slots 6am and 9am. We reached around 4.30am and waited till 6...the roads are bumpy. We could see few tribals on the way. Then a ferry took ua to the other side(15min ride). From there, speed boat to the mangrove forest(amazing ), approx 20min ride. From there, a 3km trek to the limestone caves. The caves are a beautiful creation of nature, formed under the right mix of rainfall and heat. It was exhausting but totally worth it. Be prepared for long day.. keep-sunscreen/snacks/hat/mosquito repellant and lots of patience. More

title: Andaman is not just all about Sea and beach
review_text: Yes, Andaman is not just all about Sea and beach, It has got a lots of natural wonders which is very rarely seen in other parts of the India. Lime stone cave is one among them. Near about 1.5KM easy walk in the Mangrove forest and the jungles of Andaman will take you to this place. Must go place for those who looking for off beat Andaman

After you cross this 47 kms road, you ride towards the jetty and you experience how vehicles along with passengers around are transported to another location as there is no road route. title: Enjoy the experience - forest, Jarawas, ferry, boat, caves, mangroves
review_text:
While the caves itself is OK, the entire journey gives a snapshot view of Andaman life. 

Forest crossing in convoy and seeing Jarawas 
Ferry trip to reach BAratang - which is normal life for locals 
Speed boat to reach caves 
Mangroves along the coast 
Undeveloped land areas and lots of water 

Great experience for urban dwellers

title: Not really worth time, energy spent
review_text:
Even for completing the baratang tour in 12 hours...you have to rush everywhere...and finally you get to see the caves..for about 30 minutes. 
You have to get up at 3 am to catch the first convoy and also so that you can come back to port Blair by 3.30 pm. 
I would suggest you should go for this only if you have sufficient time in your itenary and also you have interest in these type of creations.

title: caves
review_text: go in first convoy which starts at 6 AM and finish it by 10AM and return to base camp. Go to Mud volcono which is 7.5kms by jeep and return by 12 noon. Return to port blair by 12.30 convoy,

title: Must Visit
review_text:
It should be a must in your bucket if you are visiting Andamans. Start at 3 am to catch the 6:00 Convoy across the Reserve Forest. Also, please follow the rules and instructions while crossing the reserve forest which is house to the Jarwa Tribe. 

From Baratang, you can proceed to Rangat and Diglipur or can return to Port Blair by afternoon convoy

title: Vacation at andaman
review_text: A must must in your itenery list. Get up early & move by 3 am latest. 120 km from Port Blair. Long convoy of vehicles can be seen during enroute. If you are lucky enough you can see jarawa tribals. Its a treat to watch. Also their huts can be seen from jarawa check post. But don't even think of taking videos and photos. Heavy fine and penalty. Lime stone cave and mangroves is just once in a life time experience. No words to describe. Just visit and feel the nature.

title: Good Day Trip in Forest - Scenic Journey
review_text: This spot comes on lesser priority if you have not checked places like Ross island, cellular jail, havelock, neil island. One has to leave early in the morning from port blair, as Jarava forest reserve entry timings are fixed. ( 6 to 9 am). Road to Baratang is through lush green forest. Car will drop you near jetty from where you have to board Ferry to reach opposite side of bank. From there you will get motor boat for going to the caves. Car can be hired between 4500 to 7500 Rs. Tickets to ferry can be purchased directly and further motor boat tickets are available at 750 Rs. / Person. There is option of hiring complete 10 seater boat at negotiated price. If you travel as per above break up , you can save some money against bookings done by agent. One has to walk about 20 minutes on island to reach the caves. Guide is available at payment of Rs.200 to 400. However, don't hurry during visit as per guide's instructions. There is lot of time available as the forest enrtry from Baratang will not open before 3 pm. Trek to the caves and caves (though open in limited area) is worth an experience. Forgot to mention Local Tribes - Jaravas can be easily spotted on the way through forest. Their houses are also worth noticing. More

title: Good
review_text: The drive to Baratang is worth the visit and additionally you get to see the limestone caves which is a small walk from the jetty after crossing the mangroves. However, the cave is very small and gets over in maybe 15-20 mins and the route to get to Baratang is really long. Hence, its better to leave early if you do not want to be rushed.

title: Limestone Cave
review_text: Wonder of nature: Lime stone cave at the Baratang Iceland waiting for you to be discovered with its thousands years workshop of nature. Through jarwa tribal passage it's the secrect treasure of nature preserved for visitors. Have to walk around 3km to reach following by 30 minute boat and several hour road journey from the Port Blair.

title: Dangerous to go there without protection
review_text: We were travelling with a friend from Forest Department and were lucky to get a boat to visit Limestone Caves around 3 pm. The motor boat ride from Baratang Jetty to the point near Limestone caves was approx 30 minutes. When we landed there, it started to drizzle which gradually increased to normal rain. The most part of the walkway from the point of disembarkation till the caves is not paved and rains made it slushy and very slippery. I slipped at a point and injured my face and hand, falling on the ground. We expected this to be a world class caves structure and a tourist attraction but unfortunately it was not like that. There were no proper footpaths, no lighting arrangement inside the caves, no one to guide us and on top of that we were not wearing gum boots, were struck by leeches. My friend's daughter showed us a snake too. Area near the shore had a board, indicating presence of crocodiles. Considering all these dangers, it is a must to be fully prepared for a jungle adventure before coming to this place, which was not indicated anywhere at the starting point. One must carry a stick and a torch as well. More

title: Adventurous trek
review_text: Loved the entrance to this island, boat rides, trek to limestone cave when i went there it was raining but still enjoyed trekking.

title: Thrilling journey more enjoyable than the caves .
review_text: Total distance is about 100 kms including a stretch of journey of about 45 kms which passes through Jarwa Reserve Forest and to be travelled in single file in a convoy without stopping , overtaking , keeping windows shut and duly guarded by security people . No two wheelers , no photographs , no interactions and offering of foodstuffs to the tribals are allowed . If it is a day trip you have to catch 6am convoy from check post at Jirketang also about 45 kms from Port Blair for which you have start at 3.30 am . title: A tiring but adventurous trip
review_text:
The travel from Port Blair to Baratang is very hectic The roads are not in very good conditions rather its a very bumpy ride. You need to catch the cab really early morning (around 2:30) in order to be a part of convoy which crosses the tribal area around 6 am. The best part of the journey was seeing a few jarava tribes on way to baratang. It was so fascinating to get a glimpse of the tribal india. Limestone caves reminded me of geography classes (stalactites and stalagmites). But didn't find them exceptional as the journey was very long hectic and tiring. 
We also saw mud volcanoes but again they were just okay. Overall it was just the glimpses of jarawa tribes which made the journey worth while. Our driver played an important part as he entertained us with stories of encounter with the tribes. 
I would say you can skip it especially if you are travelling with small kids. More

title: Creative things in a dark room.
review_text: Journey started from dum dum airport by flight.only two hours distance from dum dum to port Blair. After reaching the next day we went for baratang island.the journey was made by boat and consist of 2 hours.the scenery is so wonderful with mangroves and sea and sky.it is a island with only 11 families.here is a cave call limestone cave.in this cave we had needed emergency light because with out readymade light the cave is fully dark.the nature shows it's artistic behaviour with the limestone.some like Goutam Buddha,claw of ,car accident and many more.

title: Awesome adventure
review_text:

It was an exciting journey through the thick forest without stopping. We were fortunate enough to spot couple of jarvas on the way. On reaching Baratang left our things at forest guest house . After a quick lunch , got on a boat to lime stone caves. And what a ride it was, to and fro between the mangroves. Absolutely thrilling. title: heavenly place
review_text: The trip was so beautiful on this earth...The boat ride in the deep sea surrounding the mangroves was breathtakingly beautiful...the island was so beautiful......loved to visit and stay in the islands again..It was heavenly...no words to describe....The lime stone cave good...the visit should be based on ones journey from baratang by boat to the lime stone cave....Awesome......

title: EXCITING TREK TO LIMESTONE CAVES
review_text: Even though the road trip from Port Blair through Jirkatang Reserve forest to reach Baratang Island was a bit tiresome, the speed-boat ride through the mangrove forests was an awesome experience. Limestone caves, situated in the midst of a beautiful village unaffected by the hustle of city life provided a pristine and serene environment and offered a really a memorable experience.

title: Unique Limestone Caves
review_text: The Limestone caves at Baratang is another unique geographical feature that one can experience in Andamans. It is a full day's trip from Port Blair, but definitely worth the effort. One also needs to wear good quality shoes for the short trek from the ferry dropping point to the cave entrance. The limestone formations in the cave are very beautiful and one needs to spend some time here to appreciate their beauty. There are no places except the Forest Dept Guest house to stay overnight at Baratang and hence one needs to start early from Port Blair to make this trip.

title: place worth spending full day, lucky to see tribal "jarawa" people
review_text: you should not skip this place, you can also visit mud volcano if you have time after caves visit. pack your breakfast as you will not get anything to while traveling to baratang, if you are lucky you may see tribal "jarawa" people on this route just keep eyes open. you need to take a speedboat to reach this place, speedboat driver act as your guide on 1.2 km trek to cave. we ride over shree ganga 2 boat and guide was perumal, if you ever visit here ask for same because he was an enthusiast.

title: Natural shining lime stone caves, requiring a boat ride in magrooves + 1.2 KM trek
review_text:
Good experience away from city experience. 

Requires, 

Drive from Port Blair -> 
Jurkatang (wait till 6 AM for check-post to open) -> 
Drive through Jarawa reserve forest (no photos, spot Jarawa tribe people) -> 
Take a Ferry to cross the water -> 
Reach Baratang island -> 
Take permit and board speedboat to ride through mangroves ->

On reaching the Middle Strait jetty we took another ferry to reach the Baratang Island. This time the car did not accompany us. On one side of this jetty we saw elephants pushing lumber along the sea bed. That particular day was very rainy and on reaching Baratang Island we were in two minds about whether we should take the risk of traveling in the rains in an open motorized boat to see the limestone caves. However, we finally decided to go and took a 10 minute journey in a high speed boat to reach the island where the limestone caves are located. This journey through the sea was something I'll always remember. The rain was lashing against our faces like pin-pricks, the boat was bouncing against the waves and it seemed it was landing on boulders each time it bounced; we were hanging on to the boat for our dear lives but the boatman was as cool as ever and kept reassuring us that the sea was okay and not at all dangerous. It was scary but fun. 

The rain subsided a little after a while. As we approached the island we passed through mangrove creeks and suddenly another world opened up before our eyes. It was amazing to see a mangrove forest from so close. On reaching the island we had to walk a 1.5 km slippery stretch through the forest and many of the travelers were slipping and falling on the muddy forest floor. What I realized during my trip to the Andamans is that a light, hooded raincoat and good quality floaters are must-haves along with light easy to dry clothes. 

The actual limestone caves do not occupy a very large area. There are some very interesting shapes the stalactites and stalagmites have formed. The boatmen act as guides and carry lights with them to show the insides. A very interesting culmination to an exciting journey! 

We went back the same way we came. One must be very careful about the timings because neither the ferry back nor the convoy will budge from their scheduled departure times. one couple missed the ferry as they came running along the shore. On the way back we met some more Jarawa people. Three young Jarawa boys stopped our car and asked us for paan (betel leaf). Of course, we could not oblige. We did not have any on us and offering them food, or taking their pictures are strictly prohibited. Because it seems their immunity system is just not made to tackle food we urban people eat. 

The day was hectic but an eventful one. I would highly recommend a visit to these caves to anyone visiting the Anadamans. More

review_text: Enjoy the amazing journey through the Jarawa Reserve forests, ferry rides and then land in the mangrove area. Then a small trek of around 2 kilometres brings you to the mouth of the famous Limestone caves of Baratang Islands. Here you get to see the natural limestone formations. The stalactites and stalagmites are so beautiful. It's a great experience to watch the artistic side of Mother Nature.

title: Don't miss this
review_text:
Un like borra caves in Andhra Pradesh india, these are kept natural. One need to travel a lot to reach this place. It's actually a small expedition. Wake up very early in the morning drive for an hour and wait for the gates to forest open. Join the convoy. In this journey in thick forest you will get to see some Jarawa tribals. After crossing the forest a small ferry ride and a speed a boat ride for 30 min. Finally 2 km walk in forest will take you to the caves. This speed boat ride takes you through thick mangrove forest.After visiting caves you can visit Mud Volcano. Don't imagine it like any other volcano. It's a small heap of mud in which methane gas is produced. Worth visiting as we go all the way to baratang. 
Start early morning in portblair if you want to cover both leisurely. More

title: A day well spent !
review_text: It was an adventurous trip to the baratang islands. We took the 9 am convey and reached baratang jetty in the afternoon. From there we ourselves collected our speedboat tickets ( one can pre book tickets from the respective tour operator) and headed towards the limestone caves. We reached the beautiful mangroves after appx. half n hour of speedboat ride. From there v had to follow the trail on foot (appx. 20 mins walk) to reach the amazing limestone caves. It was like a jungle walk! We finished the tour of caves in less than half an hour and returned back to our speedboat. From there v decided to have late lunch from a nearby restaurant and returned to Portblair in the 3 pm convey. More

title: If you love nature you can go
review_text:
The journey from port blair is around 4hrs. You need to cross the police check post to reach limestone caves.Please be at check post at 9am because earlier you go chance of seeing people inside the forest are more as per local guide. you need to travel 2hrs inside the forest if you have luck you can see the tribal people on the way. 
After reaching the other side you need to take a speed boat to reach the cave and after that a walk for 1.3kms. 
If you love nature and mangrove forest then you can tick this place.

title: Nothing much to see here
review_text: This place is over hyped. You need to drive 2.30 hours from port blair, 50 minutes ride in speed boat, 1.2 km walk / trek to see the limestone caves. If you are adventurous, this place may excite you but not for people more than 40 years of age.

title: Limestones over hyped though the Mangroves can be visited
review_text: Its a overhyped place, You have to first reach Baratang , then line up and take a Boat to Limestone Caves that goes through Mangroves, then again walk through a long Jungle Path to reach the Limestone cave, the limestones have already started fading. The boat ride and Mangroves was more interesting part of the trip.

title: Beauty of nature
review_text: Baratang island is more than 100kms from Port Blair , on road. The view towards island is beautiful . We started off at 7:00 Am and reached the place where you need to wait till 9:00 AM For the gates to open which passes through forest to reach the island . You can see tribal people around in the forest if you are lucky enough . Government is very strict over there and they do not allow you to take photos or stare or make funny faces at the tribal people . You should not do any gesture at them it's definitely dangerous for you too ... Quite a different experience . Then after you reach baratang you will ever taken by a boat to limestone caves ,, .. you pass through mangrove forest which is such a wonderful experience ... Finally you reach limestone caves which is a beauty of nature formed naturally with salt residing on it ..after a long tideous journey in hot sun time to feel the natural cool caves.... Be careful to stay away ,,do not touch the caves with your hand as it looses its lusture if u do so .... More

title: Ordinary fare
review_text: Hardly worth the effort. The caves themselves are good but nothing out of the world. It gets really crowded and stuffy with tourists. Overall the effort to visit isnt really justified.

title: A must visit place at Baratang
review_text: It was 40 minutes journey by boat from Baratang to Lime Stone Cave. Permission of forest department at Baratang is must to visit Lime Stone Cave. Booked tickets @ 600/- each. Availed Baratang Tourist Fibre Boat. After 40 minutes journey by boat through a wide creek, we reached to the jetty and then did another fifteen minutes trekking through a tropical forest to reach the Lime Stone Cave. Lime Stone is a sedimentary rock formed by the bottom of the sea. We have found there are a huge sedimentary lime stone formation in different shapes and in different patterns inside the cave. Some of them which are hanging from the top, some growing from the ground. As we proceeded into the cave more, we were not able to see anything more in front of us due to the cave at that point is so dense, deep and dark. Our guide helped us by switched on a torch. Inside the cave some where is slippery so it is better to wear shoes for safety. It is obviously a must visit place at Baratang. More

1. We woke up at 2 am! Yes 2 am to take the renter car with a driver for Rs.4500/- for the day; we left for Baratang at 3 am. 

2. The reason for leaving at 3 am is logical though. You will see a convoy forming as you head towards the adivasi area or specifically known as thw Jarwa tribe reserve. You; as in your car will try and become a part of the first convoy which registers at the checkpoint and leave at 6 am sharp. In order to cover the distance and hold your spot you must leave at 3 and reach the checkpoint by 4:30am. We were number 32 in a convoy of 106 cars/vehicles 

3. Before the convoy is allowed to pass, you are required to fill up some documents with identity proof. These documents are normally submitted by your driver to the forest official while you wait for the clock to strike 6. The acceptance means you will be allowed to go through. 

4. The convoy moves at a speed of 40kmph and does not stop. No car is allowed to stop since it is a tribal reserve. We were lucky enough to spot some jarwas but we obeyed the rules and did not click any pictures. The tribe is on the road of civilization though; they wear clothes just like the urban population while minutely expressing the culture of their tribe. 

5. After about an hour and a half, we reached a jetty. Our driver was superb. He hurried us off on the ferry and then brought the car on the ferry too! This ferry ride is about 10 mins long and is Rs8/- per person. Once you get off the ferry, run towards the permit counter and get yours to get on the boat to baratang island. This permit is free of cost. And one person can check in upto a group of 10. So choose the fastest in your group to line up. 

6. You then get on a speedboat. The speedboat then takes you to the island where the limestone caves are. The ride is fun and about 35 mins long and Rs.600/- and includes guide services per person. Once you get down from the speed boat; you have to walk about 1.7 kms to get to the limestone caves. This is where its gets really tiring for old people. People with mobility issues have a tough time. Imagine coming all this way and not being able to see the caves; and therefore you should think if its worth risking their health. They can sit at a middle point and wait for you if they dont want to walk. 

7. The Limestone caves are a marvel. But with humans touching the walls and the heat, the pure white shimmering white walls have turned black. But if you spend a quite moment in there you will realize how marvellous nature is. There is a rush at all times as the speedboat operators try and get as many runs as possible. 

8. You return via speedboat and then take a jeep ride to the mud volcano. It was a very hot day and we could have easily given the mud volcano a miss; but the curiosity got the bette of us and we did end up going. Our driver who had brought the car over the ferry saved us Rs. 300/- which is he the fare for hiring the jeep to mud volcano. 

9. The same ferry ride back and the same convoy system will get you back to Andaman- Port Blair at about 4 pm in the evening. 

10. On your way back stop by the market to indulge in some souvenir shopping or spend some time at the marine drive and enjoy the evening breeze. You will surely sleep like a baby after this trip to Baratang. More

At Middle Strait, it is interesting to note how buses/vehicles alight and board on the ferry to reach either side of the middle strait. 

Though the journey up to Middle Strait was tedious, but the tediousness vanished when we saw a rare scene, ie. the entry of bus & cars on the deck of the ferry, and it was thrilling. There is a separate space reserved for the passengers on ticket basis. We got down at Nilambur Jetty and took a speed boat, which accommodates 6 persons to the lime stone cave. The trip is very adventurous and at the same time very dangerous also, but we were provided with life jackets. The boatman accompanied us like a guide with a powerful electronic torch light. The vast expanse of the mangrove forests on the waterline was a relish to the eyes.. But the speedboat trip was more than one hour, and it was terrifying whenever the boat faced a wave – akin to a road travel with lots of pot-holes. Such is the experience when we faced every ripple on the sea. Finally we reached a small jetty, and from where, we proceeded to the Limestone Cave, which was weathered by rains, many a storm and tsunamis. As a result of these natural phenomena, the limestone cave is taking different shapes, and the visitors attribute it to their whims and fancies. The return trip was also thrilling, fearful and awesome. At Baratang, at AR Restaurant we had our lunch. Again, from Nilambur jetty to Middle Strait, by a ferry and from Middle Strait, we travelled by bus. The entire road is in the reserve forest, and we were fortunate to see two Jarawa women carrying logs of wood. On the whole, the trip to Baratang was very interesting. More

title: what a journey and read for more
review_text:
the road to limestone is from jungle where jarwa tribe lives then on ferry to baratang island and then on speed boat to island where limestone cave and finally trek of approx 1.5 km on island to caves. 
1) jarwa tribe's jungle area you can only enter at designated time slots of 6am, 9am,12 pm and 3 pm. while coming from port blair and while returning convoy is at 6:30am,9:30am, 12:30pm and 3:30pm. 
all the cars who submit their id proof of travelllers (done by cab driver) will be allowed to enter the area. people leave early to book first few positions in the convoy which enter the checkpost so that you are the first on ferry to baratang and the first one to get to the speed boat from ferry stop. and hence the fist one to enter the cave and enjoy it without much crowd. dont forget to enjoy the lemon water by islander on the cave. 
2) you will find jarwa tribe on way and they dont look like indians but africans. More

I have actually no words to describe the beautiful and memorable trip to Baratang. More

title: Thrilling ride through the forest
review_text: You have to pass through a deep forest to reach this place, also you have to take a barge ride and a speed boat ride. The journey is no doubt thrilling. You have to follow the convoy while passing through the forest. If you are lucky enough then you can get a glimpse of jarwa tribe but taking photograph or stopping the vehicle is strictly prohibited. The cave is like other limestone caves but the surrounding is much beautiful compared to the cave !!!

title: Art of Mother Nature
review_text: Baratang island houses the enchanting Limestone caves. We started at around 5:30 am in the morning for Baratang island. The journey was quite enjoyable. We drove through the Jarawa Reserve forest for over 50 Kilometers distance. The limestone caves were true art of mother nature. The stalagmites and stalactites formations were simply a visual delight. The formations revealed several known shapes and faces. Just loved it.

title: Distinct caves, Exciting journey from Port Blair
review_text: First of all it's an exciting journey from Port Blair to Baratang Islands..You have to start your journey very early(at 3-3.30 am),first to reach Jirkatang. The gate opens at 6 am.,then it will be journey of 48km through the Jarawa Protected Forest, where it's a scope to see Jarawas..It's a long but wonderful journey..From Baratang it needs a speedboat journey through Mangroves and 1.2 km walking to reach Limestone Caves..Caves are awesome, listen to the guides what they are telling about the origin of the cave,the rock formation & the relation of the architecture with the Indian religion and Gods, you'll get informations all you need.

title: Too Far, Nice Different place, need good walk to reach
review_text: Well my kids were exhausted to reach here to see, shapes of crocodile, elephant and other in Limestones, its a nice different place to experience

title: Journey from Port Blair is wonderful
review_text: We started at 6:15 a.m from Port Blair. Took the 9:00 a.m convoy at the forest check post. Drive through the forest is beautiful. After that took a large boat 15 minutes to Baratang Island. From there a 30 minutes speed boat seeing the Mangroves forest. Then a lovely walk of 1.5 km to the caves. By 12 noon we were at the caves. Returned back to Baratang Island by 1:30 p.m. Had lunch and took the large boat back. Took the last vehicle convoy at 3:30 p.m. for Port Blair again through the beautiful forest.

title: Waste of time
review_text: Its takes you over half a day to get to this cave, that they claim to be the one of the largest limestone caves discovered by man. The cave is just a few feel long. Not worth the effort it takes to get there.

title: A different experience in Andaman
review_text: We started early around 2.30 am to reach the checkpost so that we will be one among the first cars to be included in convoy. Yeah journey is through Jarawa inhabited area hence vehicles are allowed as convoys. As planned we were part of the first convoy and reached the ferry. We took the first jangar, meanwhile our driver asked us to fill the permit and ticket application. Speed boat ticket to lime stone cave costs around 600 Rs. Once it was done, our speed boat was ready. Speed boat took around 20-30 minutes to reach the lime stone cave jetty. From there we have to do a small trek for around 1km accompanied by a guide. Lime stone cave is not that big, but the trip is worth the effort. After visiting so many beached this is really different. More

title: A very long journey for an ultimately "underwhelming" experience.
review_text:
If one is to rate the entire journey and not just the Limestone Caves at Baratang, then probably my ratings for this attraction would be higher ... if you are traveling from Port Blair, you will traverse thru the restricted forest area where you may, if lucky, get to see a Jarawa tribesman, take a ferry, then a motorboat, then walk nearly two kilometers thru the mangroves before you reach the limestone caves, and there you realize that you actually enjoyed the journey more! 
Not too many stalactites ... and no stalagmites worthy of the name, and a narrow viewing hall which if crowded will spoil the entire experience. 
If part of your itinerary, be sure to tell your travel agent to ensure that you are there in the first convoy across the forest, and not the 9 AM convoy … this will ensure that you don’t have to rush thru the caves. Plan on packing a lunch of sorts because the options available at Baratang are minimal. You will have to come all the way back, nearly till Port Blair before you will find a decent restaurant. 
And if you are a camera freak, you WILL need a good flash. More

title: Mesmerizing views on the way!!
review_text: The destination is simple; not much there but the way to the caves has amazing views. It's a 30-40 mins journey by speed boat from the Baratang Jetty to the caves and it offers you very beautiful scenery; One that's generally seen in the movies. The trip to Baratang is a whole day trip so plan in advance as you need to leave by 4 am from Port Blair and you will get back after 5:30PM only. The journey through the forest is also very good. If lucky one can also see some tribal people on the way.

title: Baratang Island Tour
review_text: The tour is an entire day activity starting early in the morning around 3.30 a.m. It takes around 1.5 hr to reach the gate of the jarawa tribal area. The gates open at 6.00 a.m & then the convoy is allowed to pass. The convoy has set timings for to and fro journey & the entire forest stretch is approx 47km. If lucky one can see the tribal ppl beside the road.We saw around 10 to 12 in our entire journey. One is not allowed to stop,honk,interact or walk around. Nothing special and basically one s sitn n the car and going for a ride. Once the forest area is crossed v need to board a vessel to go to the other side for mud volcano & limestone cave. it takes around 15min. The cave & the volcano are ntn special as to what they are propagated. Extremely tiring journey & not worth it. Can be skipped. More

title: Worth visiting
review_text: These limestone caves are situated on Baratang islands. From Port Blair, this involves a car ride of about 90 minutes (48 km) of Jarawa reserve forest in a police convoy. This is followed by a ferry ride to Baratang jetty and a speed boat of around 20 minutes through mangroves. After aighting, you have to walk 1.2 k to reach the limestone caves. These caves have stalactites and stalagmites. The caves are dark and the guide uses torchlight to show the various limestone formations. Do not touch the limestone or else, it becomes black (dies). A place worth visiting!

title: Small lime stone cave
review_text: From Ranger, it's 30 mins speed boat ride. The mangrove view on the way is nice. After reaching there you need to walk for around 2km to reach the lime stone cave. Try to reach here early to avoid rush. The cave is also not very big.

title: Nontiring and scenic journey to limestone caves
review_text:
Convoy from port blair to baratang is interesting. Road is average but journey is beautiful. If you are lucky, you might spot some Jarawa tribes. 
Ferry and speed boat ride to start of baratang trek again is breathtaking. Some of the islands reminded me of Avatar movie and the hazy, & hanging mountains! 
Finally, the small trek passing thru mangroves, paddy fields, drizzles, slippery mud made it worth! 
Lastly limestone caves are just average but the overall experience from port blair to baratang and return journey was superb :)

title: A beautiful trail to limestone caves
review_text: What is more mesmerizing is the path that leads to Limestone caves. To reach baratang island, one has to pass through Jarawa forest reserve (nature at its best), one must enjoy the fresh air and greenery around while passing by the forest reserve. On reaching Baratang island, a boat ride takes us through the mangroves towards the limestone caves. A 1.5-2 km walk leads to limestone caves.The walk will surely get u closer to nature.

title: An interesting journey to the caves
review_text:
Baratang Island might seem disappointing for many as it is not like the other islands in andaman. There are no such attractive beaches but there are many natural occurrings to see and observe. 
The limestone cave is situated between the mangrove forests in Baratang Island. You have to take the high speed jet boat to reach the island where the cave is situated. The boats are very limited so one has to wait for long time to get his turn and can be quiet tiring too so be prepared. The journey is 25mins in boat and then 30 mins of walking (trekking). The boat ride can be a bit scary as the tides are high and the boat jumps on the water. When you reach the island you can see mangroves densely present and if lucky one can also spot the giant crocodile. Then after 2 kms of trekking you reach the caves. Where you can witness naturally forming limestones. 

P.S: do drink the lemon water from the stalls outside the cave. 

For me it was a great place as I am a nature lover :P so please be patient to see the greatness ;) More

title: Memorable Baratang visit
review_text:
We had an adventurous trip (not intended) to Baratang from Port blair. My agent had booked me on Monika travels for this trip. The travels bus picked us from our hotel at 3.45 am & by 6.00 am we were at the Jirkatang check post. Then the after crossing the forest, ferry ride to Baratang & then the speed boat ride to the mangroves & finally the last mile walk to reach the caves. The journey itself is the highlight. Also don't miss the Lime juice outside the caves there, very refreshing after the hectic trip. 

The adventure for us happened while returning. Our bus broke down in the middle of forest(Jarawa reserve) & we had to take a lorry ride back till the police check post & as we were reaching the check post, it was sunset time. More

title: Worth the early morning long drive to Baratang
review_text: a long drive from Port Blair (actually the wait at Jiraktang check post and then the convoy through Jarawa reserve takes maximum time) and then a short ferry to Baratang and then speed boat to limestone caves (25 mins). The boast will drop you at mangrove forest deck and from there it is about 1.5 kms walk (not and easy one). But then you get to see mangrove forest so close, walk through some of the most primitive areas (but airtel works :)) and then reach the limestone caves. It is dark and your boat guide will be your guide with lights and it is really good. active stalactites and stalagmites...different shapes. While returning back, have fresh lemonade. They use bisleri water and it is really refreshing. More

title: Worth the long time to reach the destination
review_text: A drive of about 3-4 hours from Port Blair - A small ferry ride of 15 mins - A boat ride of around 20-30 minutes - and a walk on trail of about 30 minutes - thats what it takes to reach this geographical phenomenon. The limestone caves itself might not be such a big attraction but the entire journey is fascinating. Not to mention the boat ride through mangroves. Start early from Port Blair to reach this destination

title: Interesting geographic feature.
review_text:
Getting to these caves isn't easy and requires a lot of walking to be done inside a mangrove forest. Once we reached, we saw how the salt deposits namely stalactites and stalagmites have formed such a huge cave, that is constantly growing. The guides had given their own imaginary names to some of the formations, which we found funny. 

Energy draining, but worth for the walk through the mangrove forest and the speed boat drive to reach the place.

title: Lime Stone Cave in Baratang Island
review_text: We were in Lime Stone Cave in Baratang Island on 21st October 2016. Thrilling journey by speed boat. Nice cave. Overall good experience.

title: Must see atraction for nature lovers
review_text: Limestone caves are a must see points for nature lovers & leisure travelers alike. The Road journey from Portblair to Baratang involves crossing through creeks and dense equatorial forest which is best ever.

title: Wonderful trip, great lime stone caves
review_text: A long trip through the jarwa reserve forest, ferry ride, then boat ride and walk of around 1.5 kilometres finally brings us to the place where the caves are located. The limestones formations here were natural and just amazing. Loved touching them and trying to figure out what is resembles.

title: Adventurous place to visit
review_text: It was very adventurous travel to visit lime stone caves. 20mins boat travel from Baratang Port to Lime stone entrance near Mangroves. From there we need to walk for almost 2kms which is really exhaustive and in between the forest and mangroves. The lime stones are real formations and worth to see the natural formed caves. Please carry food and water during this 1-2 hr walk.

title: Good Limestone Cave but the one in Cherrapunji is better
review_text: We can walk approx. 500 metres into the cave, with a guide and a torch light. The second half of the cave is closed by limestone formation. To reach the cave, we have to walk approx. 1.3kms. Nice Nimbu pani is available for Rs.15/- per glass on the way. But, the Limestone cave in Cherrapunji is better than this.

title: Not worth the long trip
review_text:
It would be OK if this cave was in Port Blair, Neil or Havelock. 
But a trip to these caves is long and exhausting. The trip to Baratang begins at 3.00 am. The car reaches the check post and waits in queue in the convoy. The convoy leaves at 6.00 am through the reserved forest which is the home of the Jarwa tribe. The only good thing about this trip is to be able to see a few Jarwas on the way, if one is lucky. It is strictly forbidden to take any photos, in this stretch or to interact with the Jarwas in any way if one happens to see them. 
Once the convoy reached the other side of the reserved forest, we had too take a short ferry ride to Baratang. From here we were supposed to take a speed boat to the Limestone Cave. Since there were no boats available, we were made to wait for two hours. After this we had another half an hours boat ride to the island where the cave is situated. We got off the boat and were made to jog to the cave as there was not enough time. (We had lost time waiting for the boat) After a hurried visit to the cave we were rushed back to the boat. A 16 hour day just to visit a cave for a few seconds. NOT WORTH IT. More

title: Unique!
review_text: Arguably the most visited place (main reason for our visit as well) in this remote Baratang region of the Andamans. The long journey was worth it - hopping from main ferry to a small boat to approach the mouth of the caves, then the traverse along narrow ridges of the sharp limestone drops. All in all, a memorable experience. Be watchful not to get hurt though.

title: Unbelievable Natural formations
review_text: The journey for Bartang itself is full of adventures. The road goes through the Great Andaman Trunk Road which is the Jarawa area. You have to cross to the other side by a barge and then take speed boat to the area where there are these mangrove forests. There is a trek for another 1.4 km. The caves are unbelievable. There are different formations, which happen due to the limestone coming in contact with water dissolves and forms stalactites. Guide is available of the speed boat itself. Though its a small cave its worth visiting.

title: Family outing
review_text:
This place is a again one of the most beautiful places. To visit this place one should taken the permit from the forest department which generally handled by the tour organizer. 
We need to travel 125 kms to reach limestone cave. 
We need to travel through bus or private vehicle distance of 110. Out of which 49 kms is jarawas tribal reserve area. Where you need to take the permit from the police and forest department. 
We cannot stop our vehicle in between the journey of 49kms. Generally for every 10 vehicle one escorts vehicle of police will flow. 
And reach to the place through Freey and small speed boat. This is place is amazing place with lots of limestone collection. More

title: Excellent Natural formations
review_text: We under went a lengthy but very interesting journey through the road ways crossing the Reserve Tribal forest, boat rides and post that a trek of 2 kilometers, finally reaching the famous Limestone caves. The natural lime stone formations were simply amazing. We got to see the beautiful creations of mother nature. There were limestone formations that resembled known animals and other objects.

title: Caves with stones/ rocks that grow.
review_text: Though the journey is long but one can see the Jarwas the tribal people which is exciting. While entering the destination the mangrove forest is ultimate experience.The walk to the cave is also good and the best part is the cave itself which makes the trip a must visit.

title: Limestone cave and lovely mangrove
review_text: Mangrove at bartang is really nice and lime stone cave will make u speechless. Only one problem is those guides they are always in a hurry

title: Mangrove tree ride to caves.
review_text: This place is must visit place in order to have jungle boat ride with dense mangrove tree around. And have a trek for about 15mins which is through small village in an island In order to see the limestone caves. Caves are really natural ones which has got different animal shapes as though it looks like sculptured by artists. The boat rider explains about caves nicely by showing us different shapes which they resemble like.

title: Beautiful Limestone Caves
review_text: We reached the limestone caves after a long journey through the Jarawa Reserve Forest, ferry ride to Baratang island, a speed boat ride and then around 1.5 Kilometres walk to the caves. The journey was soothing and enjoyable. The caves had several limestone formations. We were amazed to see that one of the natural formations had shape like a tree and another like Ganesha. This was my first experience seeing Stalactites & Stalagmites. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

title: Journey to Limestone caves at Baratang
review_text:
The two hour drive through the Jarawa territory gets you to a place called Middle Straight where a government ferry takes you across to Baratang. While on the ferry you can take in the lovely greenery just kissing the waters. 
From there you hire a speed boat which takes you to Baratang limestone caves. Again the identity card, paper works etc. (it costs Rs 450/- per head for the speedboat) 
The outboard really zips you through the mangrove forests. We did see an alligator basking in the sun but the boat was too fast for me to click. As you near your destination the boat slows down and you wind your way through the smaller lanes of the mangroves. It’s a wonderful sight and one is reminded about the movie “Black Water” 
You get off the speed boat near the mangroves and walk. It’s a good trek for about 2 kms with tall trees and lush greenery all around you. 
The path twists and turns till you reach the limestone caves. 
You get to see more stalactites than stalagmites. It is a good place for people who are interested in geology. 

I would advice tourists visiting the caves to carry a powerful torch. Walking shoes is an added advantage for the trek. More

title: A natural wonder
review_text:
A visit to the Baratang Islands is a must do at any cost primarily because of the journey ( passing through Jarawa Reserve Forest ) and destination ( Limestone Caves ) .The journey is partly by road, and partly by boat.The road passes through a No Overtaking convoy passing through the Jarawa Reserve forest area and then a ferry ride to Baratang Island. 
A motorboat takes you from Baratang Jetty to the limestone caves through Mangrove Creeks which is a different experience all together. 
The motorboat drops you at a jetty from where the caves are a km or 2 trek through the village. 
The limestone caves are a natural beauty and best time to visit is in the morning hours.One can see interesting limestone structures and stalactite and stalagmites. More

title: Amazing place!
review_text: If you ever travel to Andamans (which you must, by the way), don't miss this limestone cave of Baratang island. With a bit of an adventure (when we went it was raining, so pathway into the cave wasn't clear), you will be amazed to go into this cave full of hanging white stones. Terrific experience!

title: Excellent and Must Visit Place at Baratang.
review_text: Such a beautiful thrilling atmosphere in this area. Very Romantic island and this cave is made by naturally. This cave is too far from Port Blair. You have to book in advanced for Baratang Tour from any local travel agency. Best time to go to this place with the 1st Convoy. It is a fully Tribal area. After registration all passengers details then the vehicle can enter inside with the convoy. After a long Jarawa Jungle journey, you reach Baratang Island. From there 20 mins by boat to reach Lime Stone Cave. At the entrance area was very thrilling. You have to walk a long to reach the cave. Inside the cave very dark and cold. Guide will tell you all details and history of the cave. Please carry water bottles and some dry foods with you because inside the cave no shop is there and you have to walk few kms. You can carry a torch light with you. At last I can say it was just amazing journey and experience. More

title: Must visit
review_text:
Visited Baratang island and amazing limestone caves with my family this April..its a must visit place for all if you are visiting Andaman.. 
its a full day trip..as Baratang island is about 100 km from portblair 
on the way if you are lucky as we were you could spot some Jarawa tribes too. 
the journey to the Limestone cave itself is an amazing experience 
you can witness the amazing art work by nature

title: Hanging white stones....
review_text: The journey on to these is really mesmerising which covers all the way through Tribal reserves, A bay crossing between Baratang and Uttara Jetty, one hour journey from Uttara jetty including Mangroove area . These caves are nearer to Baratang Jetty . The sea journey starts from the other side of the sea called Uttara Jetty. The Sea Journey is through boats, 45minutes to one hour journey.

title: Aesthetic Limestone Caves
review_text:
The beautiful lime stone caves are located in Baratang Island which is about 100 kms from Port Blair city. 
We started our journey from Port Blair with our Driver cum Guide in his vehicle at around 4 am. The drive was an awesome experience through villages, hills, plains and coconut plantations. Our first halt was at a village connecting to the Great Andaman Trunk Road. There was a big queue of the vehicles here awaiting for the Gates to open to go through the Jarawa Tribal Reserve. Once the gate opened, our driver drove us through the reserve for about 50 kms and we reached a jetty from where we took a ferry to Baratang Island. From the Baratang Island, a short half an hour speed boat ride took us to Limestone caves. There was a guide accompanying us. We walked about a kilometer across the mangrove forest crossing a village and fields to reach the caves. 

The caves were a bit dark. Our guide carried a torch and we were able to see the beautiful natural formations in the flash light of the torch. The Stalactites & Stalagmites formations were really mesmerizing. More

title: Beautiful Caves
review_text: Thirty minutes on a speed boat from Baratang Jetty, you will reach this jetty near to the caves. A couple of kilometers walk from there through the mangrove forest on either side and then through a small village, you will reach the caves. A guide will accompany you and explain about the formation and features of the caves. It is pretty dark inside, carrying a flash light may help.

title: One of the best lime stone cave
review_text: You can be thrilled while going to the cave. From Port Blair, you have to go by car. In between you can see Jarwa tribe on the road. You have to take a boat to go to Baratang, and then you have to apply for permit, and ride a speed boat. You shall be on a jetty, where lots of mangrove trees are there, then walking in between the mangrove forest, there is a field. After crossing the field you can reach the cave. Jetty to cave is 1.2 KM. By the way the water is crocodile infested. Natural formation of different images are mind blowing.

title: Awesome baratang
review_text:
Superb drive from Port Blair to North through misty hills .arconut ,banana ,n coconut plantations .Dense forests and a intense drive through the maneater tribal area of zorawars .They are living off the Forrest and are negroid breed naked and dwell off the natural resources . 
History has it that during 1957 when the highway road NH 4 which ( is single lane )was being constructed 300 persons were killed by them for trespassing their area. 
This road only connects to baratang island and we had six sighting of these allusive tribe ...it was a intense experience. 
Reaching the jetty for cross over to island is a two big ferries costing RS 8 per person .Govt. Eating and restrooms are available . 
Then to the speed boats to travel through 
Malay straits 1 hr journey with mangroves and a intense walk through the mangroves and a short 15 minutes trek to the caves . 
A picturesque village of 80 families greet you and you are transported to another world . 
The caves though small are a good example of time and money well spend . 
Food is only available at takeoff jetty point. 
IMG More

title: Must visit
review_text:
The caves are beautiful and the way upto them, the speed boat ride, mangroves and walking up to the caves just builds it up. 
In the end you are left mesmerized by it all in totality. 
we visited it when the the sky was overcast, cool wind was blowing with light showers, which made the whole trip lovely. 
you may have to cough up a few hundred rupees extra per person for boat trip as number of boats were reduced recently and the person in charge just tells you that all tickets are sold out for the day. 
since most are travelling from Port Blair and convoy through Jarawa area leaves at 6 AM or 9 AM, catching the 6 AM convoy might prevent the hassle of tickets. Be sure to ask your operator about tickets. More

title: Caves at its best
review_text: Best place to visit at baratang island.This place is adventurous as you have to take a jetty ride to this island through the mangrove forest.On reaching the destination you shall love its beauty and formation of the caves from limestone.

title: Good to visit but NOT in the must do list
review_text:
It is good to see, especially for kids or if you have not seen Stalactites & Stalagmites before. It's a different type of experience. 
Only issue is, the time it takes to visit the place. It takes ~4 hrs. of bus journey followed by Ship & speed boat ~15 mins each and 20 mins of trek each side. It takes up the full day. 
Although I must admit, the 15 mins journey in speed boat through the mangrove is beautiful. 
Also you might spot a couple of tribals during the bus journey. 
Can skip if you have less days. Instead spend time in Havelock & Neil Islands.

title: Prepare for adventure!
review_text:
If you truly possess a spirit of adventure, a journey to Baratang Island is one you must not miss. Not just because of the destination but because the journey itself is worth writing about. Plan to depart around 4am from Port Blair & make sure you have a good vehicle and guide with you. The early morning trip takes you across 1 hour of terrain across villages, misty hills & plains finally reaching the first pit stop at a village connecting the Great Andaman Trunk Road. You can have your early morning cuppa here, with reasonably ok wash rooms, and a huge queue of vehicles awaiting approval to depart when the gates are opened. The Govt has done a fantastic job of strictly controlling the journey through the Jarawa Tribal Reserve. Vehicles are only allowed to depart in convoys 4 times a day with the first one departing at 6am. Security patrols escort the convoy at its front & rear and you cannot stop or take any pictures throughout this reserve forest. This is to protect the indigenous Jarawa tribals and they truly should be left alone if they are to survive. Take back great memories with you as your day ends with reaching Port Blair around 4pm. More

title: Spectacular, adventerous
review_text:
We visited this place during family trip. From Andaman we has to travel 6 hours on car and then on ferry and then finally tracking our way to Limestone Caves. 
But believe me it is worth going. 
Be sure to hire a good guide even if you have to pay a little bit extra (max 500 RS for 4 people...actually that is not much) 
It was sunny and hot on the daay we visited this place. 
When back to port, there is no good place to have food. 
But there is an oasis...a canteen on rooftop thhat serves unlimited amount of Dal, Sambhar, Rice and two dry curries for 100 INR. Very good value for money and the taste is awesome. 
For people going to Andaman, Baratang, limestone caves is a good day trip. 
Recommended for people who are willing to take a tiring but rewarding day!! More

title: Nature's Surprise
review_text: There is half an hour boat ride from Baratang to this cave. You are about to reach when you enter the mangrove forests. After boat ride there is also a long walk (20 min) to reach the caves but you will definitely not disappointed. Cave is pitch dark and you boat driver/guide will show around with the torch light he is carrying. Rare and delightful sight.

title: Scenic beauty of Mangroves
review_text: The convoy journey to Baratang is a waste. The jeep driver would tell stories about the tribe which is completely illogical. Jarawa sighting would be made equivalent to alien explorations, with people showing off about the number of Jarawa they saw. There is nothing much in limestone caves either. The guide would draw resemblance of cave structure with different figures eg.Ganesh idol. One should visit this place only for the boat ride from jetty to caves. Surrounded by mangroves from both sides, narrow water passage leading to a small wooden platform, would seem like a live movie scene. Sit in the front of the boat,where water drops splash on your face, and you would be the most happiest person. More

title: Nature's creation
review_text: It is a one day tour... Going early in the morning and coming back in the evening... Very tiring... But a must see place... Going through jarwa area in convoy is an experience ...

title: Beautiful walk to a beautiful cave!
review_text: This cave can be accessed by a 30 minute boat ride plus another 30 minutes or so of walk through part mangrove, part flat and part slightly hilly walk. There are some steps to climb up and down as well in between. The boat that takes you there will have a guide who will accompany you there throughout and show you around the cave. The cave is intimidating. I loved the eerie feel of it. The limestone is white and ghostly. But at the same time really beautiful!

title: Wonderful Trip
review_text: It was enjoyable trip. Hundreds of cars gathered at forest gate 50 km away from Port Blair. Went through deep forest with Police protection further 50 km. May see tribal on the way. Then went to Baratang by motor boat. Walk about 1 km to Lime caves. Wonderful experience.

The vehicles pass the land in a convoy with a police vehicle leading the convoy. No overtaking, no speed limit breaking, no stoppage or coming down from the vehicle. Also no to photography, giving food to locals. Even our bus driver cautioned us not to wave hands. We have been told, it is sheer luck to see some Jarawa. Eventually I was luckier than my wife, to have a glimpse of two people standing on the roadside. The journey ended in Middle Straight Jetty 
From Middle Straightr jetty, we have to cross over to Baratang by ferry service. The ferry not only carries passengers but also cars, buses etc. It is very much crowded, so we preferred to go to the upper deck. You can cross it seating in your own vehicle also but you will deprive yourself from the green beauty of the river side. 
For going to Lime stone caves again you need police permission. After getting it you have to get yourself enlisted with a speed boat and wait for your turn. Journey is about for half an hour but beautiful. You have to come back in the same boat, so normally the boat man accompanies you as a guide. This is about 5 minutes walk through a narrow bridge made of Forest produce, There are information boards in Hindi and English, eco huts, sit-outs and sit-outs. Some of the important items which people can carry along with them during this journey include some water, umbrella, cap, Wearing canvas shoes is a better idea. After the walk through the forest, cave comes in view. 
Limestone caves 
The Andaman and Nicobar Islands is a paradise for the nature lovers.- a beautiful place which provides an ideal vacation. 
Limestone caves are located at Nayadera near Wrafters Creef (near Baratang Island jetty) and a must visit for all those who are in Andaman Nicobar. The moment we got in, the caves we saw huge deposit of Limestone. The rocks inside, immediately gathered our attention. The erosion have formed some unique shapes All those who visited the caves with us expressed their astonishment and surprise about the wonders of nature. I am not a geologist. We are told that there are hundreds of such caves, but only one is open for tourists. I have no personal knowledge about the life of the rocks; and/or the geological features of that area, or even the geometry of rock-formation, their weathering and/or erosion and sedimentation. However, we were told that these rocks are as old as the origin of man-kind or may be still earlier. To me, these were just Wonderful and beautiful. Just look at the formations, imagine of anything you love or the God you worship and you visualize it in the formation. These: (i) icicle-shaped formations that hang from the ceilings of the caves, and which are produced by precipitation of minerals from water dripping through the cave ceiling and the (ii) formations that are vertical and grow from the ground up, can be seen at all over the caves. We are also told that such caves are also seen in California Cavern's Jungle. We were definitely reminded of Sea Caves of Phang Nga Bay near Phuket. The company of an experienced guide (there are so many available right there) with LED lights, will make the trip more enjoyable as you might get to know some interesting facts about the local tribes and the history of these caves. We saw fantastic formations of lime stones which is a real treat to eyes and a sensuous feel. No words can describe the caves. The caves are a sight to behold. In view of the fact that caves are natural and not man-made, but in the Island forest (in fact near the Rain forest), please do not expect infra-structure. Dogs sauntered in. Then we boarded small boats wearing very uncomfortable life jackets which seemed to me to have blocks of thermocol sewed inside. I wonder if these work in emergencies. 
The boat trip is FANTASTIC. 
MT served us packed breakfast...some tourists disposed of the empty packets in the sea...it is terrible how we abuse nature. Mangrove vegetation abounds. Then, the boat took us deep into the creeks...it is a super spectacular experience ducking to avoid the branches even as the pilot expertly steered the boat, whistling to signal arrival at blind turns. 
The jetty is large enough and a bridge with mangrove vegetation piercing it leads to the trail 
It is a gentle hike but at places the path is narrow, uneven and there are sharp drops. There is the risk of slipping. Good footwear is a MUST...ladies wearing fancy heels and flat chappals (slippers) were finding it difficult to negotiate. A few had picked up branches as walking sticks...I did not need one but it seemed like a good idea. Bamboo guard rails are fragile/rotting...grasping one or leaning is an invitation to trouble. There is a toilet here as well but long queues...and a hut that had NO AMENITIES but which was supposedly for emergencies. 
The cave fascinated me as a person with a scientific background. The lime rich water has over time created fabulous patterns which you could allow your imagination to run riot over. There was one sink hole right at the very top that let in light and air. I'd have been happy to stand and stare but our guides harried us all through..even a small stop to click a photo met with their vocal disapproval. 
To many visitors the supposed resemblances to Hindu deities was a matter of wonder. Yet others were vocal about their disappointment. They had expected more...but I gathered they did not really know what they had come to see. 
It must be understood that this is a natural creation...an object of wonder...a place where one marvels at Mother nature...this is not an urban amusement park...a mall...or a movie hall. 
The cave itself is dark and an ordinary two battery torch I carried was not much use. The guide from the boat carried brighter lights which he used for short flashes...my pictures therefore are not satisfactory. 
Food on Baratang is bad. Our group of 20 people were given lunch at a small stall by MT. We found white coloured worms in the cooked rice (some had eaten without noticing), hair and plastic fibers (from the bag in which dry rice was stored). 5 of us came down with bad tummy immediately afterwards. I did not see any stall/hotel I can recommend. If I go again, I will forget the free meal (with ticket) the travel company gives but drink the coconut water and eat the tender flesh....or carry cup noodles and ask for hot water...or eat biscuits/bread. 
Bottomline: Donot miss the boat ride to the cave and enjoy the hike. Let Mother Nature's simple display awe you. Enjoy the mangroves, birds, butterflies, flowers....breathe. More

Then one has to travel in a shared launch (they call it ship), which can be best described as 'hell'. There are limited seats, many passengers, even elderly persons have to stand the journey. The whole vessel reeks of smell of urine, and the windows are very very small, so the heat becomes unbearable in the sultry sea wind. There is not much natural beauty exclusive to this part, you are surely to see all these coastal beauty during your visit to numerous other better destinations in Andaman. Then alighting from the launch, one has to walk a very difficult stretch of land to reach the lime caves. And if you have any predetermined ideas about lime cave from similar ones in US or other parts of the world, just forget it. it is dark inside, no arrangements for lighting, so all you get to see is with torchlight from your guide. The ground is all muddy with the water from the cave, and there is huge rush of tourists and subsequent pushing and shoving. Even taking photographs with flash is difficult as huge amount of dust fill up the cave. This whole trip is to keep this area of Andaman thriving, so this is included in all package tours. And after being disappointed, you have to return through the same path, subjected to the same grinding once again. If you love to feel inner peace with nature, skip this tour. If you are one who always pick up the sugar and ajwain at the end of a meal at the restaurant, just because you paid for it, then go for it. i strictly discourage aged people, particularly with chronic illness, from going for this 8-9 hours journey, as there are no surity they'll get adequate food and drinking water during the journey.
